bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removal of claim of lien after purchase from owner developer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If one or more claims of lien under the Builders Lien Act are filed against a strata lot purchased from an owner developer, the purchaser may apply to the Supreme Court for an order for permission to pay into the court the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total amount of the claims of lien filed, and
the full amount of the holdback under section 88 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Payment into the court discharges the lien and releases the purchaser from liability to the owner developer or the lien claimant for the liens.
If the full amount of the holdback has not been paid into the court, the purchaser must release the balance of the holdback to the owner developer.

change.changenote: Section 114 (3) BEFORE amended by 2012-25-98(b), effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the dispute is resolved, the strata corporation must pay the amount to the party entitled to it as set out in the decision of the court or arbitrator.

change.changenote: Section 114 (1) (b) (ii) BEFORE amended by 2015-16-46, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving the amount owing, the strata corporation must within one week remove the lien by registering in the land title office an Acknowledgment of Payment in the prescribed form.

change.changenote: Section 123 (1.1) was added by 2009-17-18, effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).
Section 123 (1.01) and (1.02) were added by 2015-17-16, effective January 18, 2016 (BC Reg 223/2015).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limits to pet and age bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw that prohibits a pet does not apply to a pet living with an owner, tenant or occupant at the time the bylaw is passed and which continues to live there after the bylaw is passed.
A bylaw that prohibits a pet or other animal or that restricts the access of a pet or other animal to a strata lot or common property does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a guide dog or service dog, or
a dog that is a member of a retired guide or service dog team if the person who is a member of the team is an owner, tenant or occupant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In subsection (1.01), guide dog, retired guide or service dog team and service dog have the same meaning as in the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act.
Without limiting a strata corporation's power to pass any other bylaws, a strata corporation may pass a bylaw that restricts the age of persons who may reside in a strata lot.

A bylaw that restricts the age of persons who may reside in a strata lot does not apply to a person who resides in the strata lot at the time the bylaw is passed and who continues to reside there after the bylaw is passed.

change.changenote: Section 123.1 was enacted by 2022-41-16, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).
Section 123.1 (1) BEFORE amended by 2023-16-11, effective November 24, 2022 [retro from May 11, 2023 (Royal Assent)].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The strata corporation must not pass a bylaw that restricts the age of persons who may reside in a strata lot except as permitted by subsection (2).

change.changenote: Section 123.2 was enacted by 2022-41-16, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).
Section 124 (3) BEFORE amended by 2012-25-100(a), effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The use of a voluntary dispute resolution process in the bylaws does not affect a person's powers, duties or rights including, without limitation, the right to sue or begin arbitration.

change.changenote: Section 124 (4) BEFORE repealed by 2012-25-100(b), effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An admission, statement, document or record that is made only for the purpose of a voluntary dispute resolution process in the bylaws may not be used in court, in an arbitration or in any other proceeding.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite section 128, if a strata plan is a bare land strata plan or if all the strata lots in a strata plan are residential, no amendment may be made to the bylaws before the first annual general meeting unless it is approved by a resolution passed by a unanimous vote at a special general meeting.
If all the strata lots in a strata plan are nonresidential, the bylaws may be amended, in accordance with section 128, at a special general meeting held before the first annual general meeting.

the nonresidential section may amend the bylaws, in accordance with section 197, at a special general meeting of the section held before the first annual general meeting.

change.changenote: Section 128 (2) BEFORE amended by 2009-17-21, effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).

subsection.subsectiontext: An Amendment to Bylaws must be filed in the land title office within 60 days of the amendment being approved.

section.sectiontext: A repeated or continuing contravention of a reasonable and significant bylaw or rule by a tenant of a residential strata lot is an event that allows the landlord to give the tenant a notice terminating the tenancy agreement under section 36 (1) of the Residential Tenancy Act.

change.changenote: Section 138 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-78-116, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 477/2003).
change.amennote: [Note: the above was amended by 2003-81-56, effective November 17, 2003 (Royal Assent).]

subsection.subsectiontext: A repeated or continuing contravention of a reasonable and significant bylaw or rule by a tenant of a residential strata lot that seriously interferes with another person's use and enjoyment of a strata lot, the common property or the common assets is an event that allows the strata corporation to give the tenant a notice terminating the tenancy agreement under section 36 (1) of the Residential Tenancy Act.

change.changenote: Section 139 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-17, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rental disclosure by owner developer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner developer who rents or intends to rent one or more residential strata lots must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file with the superintendent before the first residential strata lot is offered for sale to a purchaser, or conveyed to a purchaser without being offered for sale, a Rental Disclosure Statement in the prescribed form, and
give a copy of the statement to each prospective purchaser before the prospective purchaser enters into an agreement to purchase.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner developer may change the statement by changing the number of strata lots to be rented or the rental period for the strata lots, or both, if the owner developer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: owns all the strata lots in the strata plan, or
obtains the prior approval of the change by a resolution passed by a 3/4 vote at an annual or special general meeting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of the 3/4 vote referred to in subsection (2), the following persons are not eligible voters:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person voting in respect of a nonresidential strata lot;
a person voting in respect of a residential strata lot which is currently rented;
the owner developer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner developer who changes a statement under subsection (2) must immediately

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file the changed statement with the superintendent,
give a copy of the changed statement to each purchaser who received a previous version of the statement, and
give a copy of the changed statement to each prospective purchaser before the prospective purchaser enters into an agreement to purchase.

change.changenote: Section 140 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-17, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Contravention of disclosure requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the owner developer contravenes section 139, the purchaser of a residential strata lot may cancel the agreement to purchase without penalty.

change.changenote: Section 141 BEFORE re-enacted by 2022-41-18, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restriction of rentals by strata corporation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The strata corporation must not screen tenants, establish screening criteria, require the approval of tenants, require the insertion of terms in tenancy agreements or otherwise restrict the rental of a strata lot except as provided in subsection (2).
The strata corporation may only restrict the rental of a strata lot by a bylaw that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibits the rental of residential strata lots, or
limits one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the number or percentage of residential strata lots that may be rented;
the period of time for which residential strata lots may be rented.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2) (b) (i) must set out the procedure to be followed by the strata corporation in administering the limit.

change.changenote: Section 142 (4) was added by 2009-17-22, effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).
Section 142 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-19, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limits to rental restriction bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, "family" and "family member" have the meaning set out in the regulations.
A bylaw referred to in section 141 (2) does not apply to prevent the rental of a strata lot to a member of the owner's family.
A rental of a strata lot to a family member under this section creates an assignment of the owner's powers and duties under section 148.
If the bylaws of a strata corporation include a bylaw referred to in section 141 (2) (b) (i), a residential strata lot that has been rented

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a member of the owner's family, or
under an exemption from the bylaw granted or allowed under section 144

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is not to be considered, for the purposes of that bylaw, as a residential strata lot that has been rented.

change.changenote: Section 143 (1) (part) BEFORE amended by 2009-17-23(a), effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals does not apply to a strata lot until the later of

change.changenote: Section 143 (2) BEFORE amended by 2009-17-23(b), effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (1), if a strata lot has been designated as a rental strata lot on a Rental Disclosure Statement in the prescribed form, and if all the requirements of section 139 have been met, a bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals does not apply to that strata lot until the earlier of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the date the strata lot is conveyed by the first purchaser of the strata lot, and
the date the rental period expires, as disclosed in the statement.

change.changenote: Section 143 (3) and (4) were added by 2009-17-23(b) and (c), effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).
Section 143 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-19, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rental restriction bylaw does not apply to some strata lots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), a bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals does not apply to a strata lot until the later of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one year after a tenant who is occupying the strata lot at the time the bylaw is passed ceases to occupy it as a tenant, and
one year after the bylaw is passed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (1), if a strata lot has been designated as a rental strata lot on a Rental Disclosure Statement in the prescribed form, and if all the requirements of section 139 have been met, a bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals does not apply to that strata lot until,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a Rental Disclosure Statement filed before January 1, 2010, the earlier of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date the strata lot is conveyed by the first owner of the strata lot other than the owner developer, and
the date the rental period expires, as disclosed in the Rental Disclosure Statement as it read on December 31, 2009, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a Rental Disclosure Statement filed after December 31, 2009, the date the rental period expires, as disclosed in the Rental Disclosure Statement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Even if a Rental Disclosure Statement filed before January 1, 2010 is changed under section 139 (2) after December 31, 2009, subsection (2) (a) of this section applies.
Subsection (1) (b) does not apply to a bylaw that is passed under section 8 by the owner developer.

change.changenote: Section 144 (3) and (4) BEFORE amended by 2009-17-24, effective December 11, 2009 (BC Reg 312/2009).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the owner wishes a hearing, the strata corporation must hear the owner or the owner's agent within 3 weeks after the date the application is given to the strata corporation.
An exemption is allowed if the strata corporation does not give its decision in writing to the owner

paragraph.paragraphtext: within one week after the hearing, or
if no hearing is requested, within 2 weeks after the application is given to the strata corporation.

change.changenote: Section 144 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-19, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemption from rental restriction bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner may apply to the strata corporation for an exemption from a bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals on the grounds that the bylaw causes hardship to the owner.
The application must be in writing and must state

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the reason the owner thinks an exemption should be made, and
whether the owner wishes a hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the owner wishes a hearing, the strata corporation must hear the owner or the owner's agent within 4 weeks after the date the application is given to the strata corporation.
An exemption is allowed if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the strata corporation does not give its decision in writing to the owner,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if a hearing is held, within one week after the hearing, or
if no hearing is requested, within 2 weeks after the application is given to the strata corporation, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner requests a hearing under subsection (2) (b) and the strata corporation does not hold a hearing within 4 weeks after the date the application is given to the strata corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption granted by the strata corporation may be for a limited time.
The strata corporation must not unreasonably refuse to grant an exemption.

change.changenote: Section 145 BEFORE repealed by 2022-41-19, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rental agreement in contravention of rental restriction bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an agreement for the rental of a residential strata lot contravenes a bylaw that prohibits or limits rentals, the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not in contravention of the bylaw, and
may, within 90 days of learning of the landlord's contravention, end the tenancy agreement without penalty by giving notice to the landlord.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tenant ends a tenancy agreement under subsection (1), the landlord must pay the tenant's reasonable moving expenses to a maximum of one month's rent.

change.changenote: Section 147 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-14-189, effective December 1, 2007 (BC Reg 354/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A landlord may assign to a tenant some or all of the powers and duties of the landlord that arise under this Act, the regulations, the bylaws or the rules, but may not assign to a tenant the landlord's responsibility under section 131 for fines or the costs of remedying a contravention of the bylaws or rules.

change.changenote: Section 148 (2) BEFORE amended by 2007-14-189, effective December 1, 2007 (BC Reg 354/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a residential strata lot is leased under a long term lease, the tenant is assigned the powers and duties of the landlord under this Act, the regulations, the bylaws and the rules for the term of the lease.

change.changenote: Section 148 (7) BEFORE amended by 2022-41-20, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

order an owner, tenant or other person to stop contravening this Act, the regulations, the bylaws or the rules;

bcl:section.bcl:text: The requirements and procedures regarding authorization for suits and liability for expenses and judgments in suits by and against the strata corporation, as set out in sections 166, 167, 169, 171 and 172, apply with appropriate changes to an arbitration in which the strata corporation is a party.

subsection.subsectiontext: The strata corporation may refer a dispute with an owner or tenant to arbitration if the dispute concerns a matter set out in subsection (3).
An owner or tenant may refer a dispute with the strata corporation or with another owner or tenant to arbitration if the dispute concerns a matter set out in subsection (3).
A dispute may be referred to arbitration if it concerns any of the following:

change.changenote: Section 177 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2012-25-103, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 178 (1), the strata corporation may refer to arbitration a dispute with an owner or tenant if the dispute concerns a matter set out in subsection (3) of this section.

Subject to section 178 (1), an owner or tenant may refer to arbitration a dispute with the strata corporation or with another owner or tenant if the dispute concerns a matter set out in subsection (3) of this section.

subsection.subsectiontext: A dispute cannot be referred to arbitration once a court proceeding has been commenced.
The court must stay its proceedings unless the court is satisfied there is good reason to continue its proceedings.

Section 178.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2015-16-47, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of tribunal proceeding on arbitration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a dispute must not be referred to arbitration under section 177 (1) or (2) of this Act once a tribunal proceeding has started under section 12 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in relation to the same dispute.
A dispute may be referred to arbitration under section 177 (1) or (2) of this Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the civil resolution tribunal notifies the parties of its refusal to resolve the dispute, or
the parties agree to withdraw from a tribunal proceeding under section 21 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in relation to the same dispute.

change.changenote: Section 179 (6) (part) BEFORE amended by 2022-41-23, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

change.changenote: Section 184 (4) BEFORE amended by 2022-41-24, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The arbitrator may admit evidence that he or she considers relevant to the issues in dispute, whether or not that evidence would be admissible in a court.

change.changenote: Section 185 (1) (part) BEFORE amended by 2022-41-24, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The arbitrator may make whatever decision he or she considers just having regard to this Act, the regulations, the bylaws and the rules, and may do one or more of the following:

change.changenote: Division 5, sections 189.1 to 189.6 was enacted by 2012-25-105, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).
Section 189.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2015-16-48, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Strata corporation initiating tribunal proceeding

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A strata corporation may make a request under section 4 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act asking the civil resolution tribunal to resolve a claim concerning anything described in section 6 or 7 of the Schedule to that Act.
In making a request under subsection (1), the strata corporation is consenting to having the claim resolved by the tribunal under the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act.

change.changenote: Section 189.2 BEFORE repealed by 2015-16-48, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Owner or tenant initiating tribunal proceeding

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), an owner or tenant may make a request under section 4 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act asking the civil resolution tribunal to resolve a claim concerning anything described in section 6 or 7 of the Schedule to that Act.
An owner or tenant may not make a request referred to in subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner or tenant requested a council meeting under section 34.1 of this Act and the matter was not resolved under that section, or
the civil resolution tribunal, on request by the owner or tenant, directs that the requirements of paragraph (a) do not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an owner or tenant makes a request under subsection (1) in relation to a claim against the strata corporation, the strata corporation is required to participate as a party to the tribunal proceeding in relation to that claim.

change.changenote: Section 189.3 BEFORE repealed by 2015-16-48, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Addition of strata corporation as a party
bcl:section.bcl:text: The strata corporation is required to participate as a party to the tribunal proceeding if,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under section 31 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, the case manager considers that a strata corporation should properly be a party to a dispute, and
the dispute concerns a claim that the tribunal is dealing with under section 6 or 7 of the Schedule to that Act.

change.changenote: Section 189.5 BEFORE repealed by 2015-16-48, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Relationship with court proceedings and arbitrations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 15 and 16 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act apply to the relationship between court proceedings and a tribunal proceeding in respect of the same claim that concerns anything described in Part 2 [Strata Property Matters] of the Schedule to that Act.

Section 178.1 of this Act applies to the relationship between arbitration under Division 4 of this Part and a tribunal proceeding in respect of the same claim that concerns anything described in Part 2 [Strata Property Matters] of the Schedule to the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act.

change.changenote: Section 189.6 was enacted by 2012-25-105, effective July 13, 2016 (BC Reg 171/2016).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Proceedings within jurisdiction of civil resolution tribunal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the Supreme Court determines that all matters in a proceeding before it are within the jurisdiction of the civil resolution tribunal, the Supreme Court must dismiss the proceeding unless it is not in the interests of justice and fairness for the civil resolution tribunal to resolve the dispute.
When deciding whether it is in the interests of justice and fairness for the civil resolution tribunal to resolve a dispute under this section, the Supreme Court may consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the use of electronic tools in the process of the civil resolution tribunal would be unfair to one or more parties in a way that cannot be accommodated by the civil resolution tribunal;
whether an issue raised by the dispute is of such public interest or importance that the dispute would benefit from being resolved by the Supreme Court to establish a precedent;
whether an issue raised by the dispute relates to the constitution or the Human Rights Code;
whether an issue raised by the dispute is sufficiently complex to benefit from being resolved by the Supreme Court;
whether all of the parties to the dispute agree that the dispute should be resolved by the Supreme Court;
whether the claim should be heard together with a claim currently before the Supreme Court.

section.marginalnote: Application of Company Act to voluntary winding up of strata corporation
section.sectiontext: Except as otherwise provided in this Act and the regulations, the provisions of the Company Act that apply to a voluntary winding up apply to the winding up of a strata corporation except that

paragraph.paragraphtext: a reference to "registrar" in the Company Act must be read as a reference to the registrar as defined in this Act, and
documents required to be filed with the registrar must be filed in the land title office.

Section 277 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-70-294, effective March 29, 2004 (BC Reg 64/2004).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by a person referred to in subsection (1), the court may order that a liquidator be appointed if the court is of the opinion that the winding up would be in the best interests of the owners, registered charge holders and other creditors.
In determining whether the winding up would be in the best interests of the owners, registered charge holders and other creditors, the court must consider

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the scheme and intent of this Act,
the probability of unfairness to one or more owners, registered charge holders or other creditors, if winding up is not ordered, and
the probability of confusion and uncertainty in the affairs of the strata corporation or the owners if winding up is not ordered.

subsection.subsectiontext: By application in writing, stating the reason for the request, an owner or tenant may request a hearing at a council meeting.
If a hearing is requested under subsection (1), the council must hold a meeting to hear the applicant within one month of the request.
If the purpose of the hearing is to seek a decision of the council, the council must give the applicant a written decision within one week of the hearing.
